inference:
The innermost circle has radius 1.
The centers of the six small circles are at $(0, \pm 2), (\pm \sqrt{3}, \pm 1)$.
The large circle is tangent to these six circles.
The distance from the center of the large circle to the center of any of the small circles is $1+1=2$.
The distance from the center of the large circle to the center of the innermost circle is 3.
The radius of the large circle is 3.
The area of the large circle is $\pi(3^2) = 9\pi$.
The area of the six small circles is $6 \times \pi(1^2) = 6\pi$.
The area of the shaded region is $9\pi - 6\pi = 3\pi$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{3\pi}$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: The large circle has radius 3, so its area is $\pi \cdot 3^2= 9\pi$. The seven small circles have a total area of $7\left(\pi\cdot 1^2\right)= 7\pi$. So the shaded region has area $9\pi - 7\pi = \boxed{2\pi}$.

inference:
The problem states that the large circle is tangent to six smaller circles, each with radius 1.  The distance from the center of the large circle to the center of any of the small circles is 2. The distance from the center of the large circle to the center of the innermost circle is 3.  This means the radius of the large circle is 3.  The area of the large circle is $\pi(3)^2 = 9\pi$. The area of each of the six small circles is $\pi(1)^2 = \pi$.  The total area of the six small circles is $6\pi$.  The area of the shaded region is $9\pi - 6\pi = 3\pi$.

$\boxed{3\pi}$
ground_truth: The large circle has radius 3, so its area is $\pi \cdot 3^2= 9\pi$. The seven small circles have a total area of $7\left(\pi\cdot 1^2\right)= 7\pi$. So the shaded region has area $9\pi - 7\pi = \boxed{2\pi}$.
